In plants [edit]. In photosynthetic organisms, NADPH is produced by ferredoxin-NADP+ reductase in the last step of the electron chain of the light reactions of photosynthesis. It is used as reducing power for the biosynthetic reactions in the Calvin cycle to assimilate carbon dioxide. Nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate, abbreviated NADP+ or, in older notation, TPN (triphosphopyridine nucleotide), is a cofactor used in anabolic reactions, such as lipid and nucleic acid synthesis, which require NADPH as a reducing agent. NADPH is the reduced form of NADP + .

ATP: In the light dependent stage of photosynthesis the energy received from the sun is stored in the form of ATP, so ATP is simply an energy carrier for the reaction that takes place in the light dependant stage of photosynthesis.

Photosynthesis is the process by which plants take light energy, water and carbon dioxide and convert it to sugar and oxygen. This is done in two cycles, a Light Dependent Cycle and a Light Independent Cycle. Both the ATP and the NADPH are used to convert the carbohydrates created in the Light Dependent Cycle to C-C bond energy. This is done in the Light Independent Cycle, or the dark reaction cycle.
